ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This class honed my craft but also taught me ways/strategies to improve it. I learned how to craft better characters, better prose, better scenes. The lessons on how much to reveal the audience and how to approach time in our writing were especially helpful! I also learned how to participate in a workshop and give constructive feedback to peers.
I love to write, and I learned so much about writing fiction, fiction as a genre, etc., in this class. The mini lectures are excellent, and the seminars are also extremely productive.
How to give and receive feedback effectively. Common introductory writing pitfalls and how to avoid them.

I deepened my knowledge of the craft of fiction through Prof. Gaige's mini-lectures and the practice of writing (both weekly exercises and full-length assignments). In this way, I think the course delivered on everything it promises.
I learned a lot about the decisions and __ that go into writing a short story, as well as ___.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The workshop format was fantastic -- it was absolutely wonderful to get feedback from my peers. I can't think of any weakness really.
I think this course is extremely well-organized; I love how the units are structured. I don't have any weaknesses in mind.

Strengths: clear general expectations, clear and actionable feedback, good class atmosphere

Weaknesses: no up-to-date documents online. The syllabus was printed and updates to it were verbal / by hand. Several students in the class often checked in with one another to clarify homework assignment contents, which caused stress for everyone. Uploading assignments online would go a long way toward alleviating confusion & stressed.

Strengths: close-knit group of classmates whom I could trust, written and oral instructor feedback, instructor's general attentiveness, class meeting structure

Weaknesses: only one full workshop per student, lack of consistent momentum of writing (i.e., huge leap from short exercises to full-length stories, and only one full-length stories)

I loved the emphasis that the course placed on writing regularly and then workshopping pieces with peers. The structured weekly exercises were great, and I loved how much freedom we had with the longer short stories. I wish there had been a few more small group workshops in addition to the class-wide workshops. I found the most effective critique session to be the small group workshop for the second short story.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I absolutely would, especially if you're interested in fiction writing!
Yes! This class is an awesome way for people who do not have much experience in fiction writing to really immerse themselves in the craft. And Professor Gaige was fantastic!
Yes, I would, absolutely! Professor Gaige is an amazing instructor, and this course facilitates writing very well.
Yes, I would absolutely recommend to anyone interested in writing fiction. The career advice Q&A at the end was also memorable and valuable.
Definitely. As I've indicated, Prof. Gaige is great, and the course is a great opportunity to practice writing fiction within the structure of an academic course.

I would definitely recommend this course to any student interested in fiction writing. It can be a little intensive (especially in the week before the longest short story is due), but I learned a lot and came out of it a better writer.
